image.altText: Drone shot of Lincoln prison

props.synopsis: Police have confirmed a 23-year-old man died in Port Lincoln Prison on June 4.

title.children: Police confirm death of 23-year-old Indigenous man in South Australian prison

image.altText: Model pic sent to scam victims

props.synopsis: In the Dubai desert lies a scam factory capable of swindling tens of thousands of people at a time. But one scammer has a secret plan that could shut the whole syndicate down.

title.children: How an insider exposed a secret scam factory in Dubai targeting Australians

image.altText: plane on tarmac with man walking down

props.synopsis: Hundreds of employees of embattled budget airline Bonza are told their employment has been officially terminated at an online meeting.

title.children: Angry Bonza staff lash out at 'disrespect' as axe finally falls on their jobs

image.altText: A graphic of a nuclear power plant with a nuclear symbol and the numbers 2040 and 2045 in the foreground

props.synopsis: As the shift away from fossil fuels gathers pace, the Coalition has turned to an emissions-free technology with a long and contentious history — nuclear fission. These are the numbers you should keep in mind when thinking about its place in Australia's energy transition.

title.children: Nuclear power explained in 12 numbers to help you understand how it fits Australia's energy needs

image.altText: Michael Mosley speaks on a morning talk show wearing a blazer, blue shirt and glasses

props.synopsis: British TV presenter Michael Mosley died of natural causes, with a post-mortem examination finding no evidence of foul play.

title.children: Television doctor Michael Mosley died of natural causes, reports say

image.altText: An Israeli military convoy

props.synopsis: The UN Security Council has backed plans for an Israel-Gaza ceasefire and Hamas has welcomed the resolution, saying it will cooperate with mediators.

title.children: 'Time to halt the killing': UN Security Council backs US plan for Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: Michelle Pearson sings on stage.

props.synopsis: Adelaide-born Michelle Pearson will perform her new show Skinny at the Adelaide Cabaret Festival with a powerful message about the dangers of unhealthy body image.

title.children: Cabaret performer tackles 'cruelty' of unhealthy body image with new show Skinny

image.altText: A smiling woman poses on a tree lined street

props.synopsis: When Amanda Hewer was in high school and still figuring out what she wanted to do with her life, trades never felt like an option. Now, she's on a quest to get more girls into the industry she loves.

title.children: Amanda went to an academic-focused, all-girls private school with zero tech options. But she wanted to be a sparky

image.altText: A large hole in the ground filled with flowers and vines and palm trees

props.synopsis: Some of the most popular places for tourists to visit in South Australia's south-east have been closed for years. Now, the local council is taking over the leases on two of the city's biggest attractions, upsetting the current operators.

title.children: It's a 'special' and 'amazing place', so why are so many tourist attractions closing here?

image.altText: A 1970s TV still of an older, balding man with a moustache and wiry eyebrows

props.synopsis: Robert Baudin printed around $2 million in fake US notes. When he (eventually) faced court, he took to the air and threatened to crash into Sydney Harbour.

title.children: This man told his wife he was printing pornography. What he was doing was much more sinister

image.altText: A black tunnel emerges from a white airliner on an airport tarmac, with people in yellow hi-vis vests standing at the entrance.

props.synopsis: Singapore Airlines has offered compensation to passengers who were on board a flight that encountered severe turbulence and led to dozens of injuries and one death last month.

title.children: Singapore Airlines offers $15,150 in compensation to passengers on flight hit by severe turbulence

image.altText: A drone shot of housing development and green pastures, divided by a single road.

props.synopsis: Developers are building half-width streets in Western Sydney due to current planning laws, as local councils and the state government blame each other over the issues the narrow roads are creating for residents.

title.children: NSW government and councils blame each other for 'absurd' half-width streets

image.altText: A grey short-hair cat sits on an open laptop on a home office desk.

props.synopsis: Australians are being warned this tax time not to double dip on working-from-home claims, make sure they have detailed records of expenses and not to lodge their tax returns too early.

title.children: Tax time is fast approaching and the ATO has a warning to those with work-from-home claims

image.altText: A composite image of Sam Short and Cate Campbell.

props.synopsis: The number of high-profile swimmers developing cancer is prompting a dermatologist to call for all major pools to be shaded by the 2032 Brisbane Olympics.

title.children: These swimmers have their sights set on the Olympics. They're also more likely to develop cancer

image.altText: A "for lease" sign on a suburban street.

props.synopsis: The Australian Information Commissioner found TICA's controversial "virtual manager" service, which allows real estate agents to track tenants indefinitely, was subject to the same restrictions as the company's formal tenancy blacklist.

title.children: Secretive database that allows real estate agents to keep tabs on renters indefinitely 'breached privacy rights'

image.altText: Tim Cook stands in front of a screen with an Apple logo.

props.synopsis: Apple is finally making its big AI move, and it matters more than most flashy big tech launches for two reasons.

title.children: Ding dong, Apple has finally arrived at the AI party. So what did it bring?

image.altText: Lani Pallister wipes her face

props.synopsis: Lani Pallister was a broken athlete when she failed to make the Olympic Games in 2021. But after battling demons both in and out of the pool, she's finally reached the holy grail.

title.children: 'Eating disorders come with a lot of shame': Lani Pallister's brave battle to qualify for Paris Games

image.altText: Climate change demonstrators hold placards during a march outside the Houses of Parliament in London.

props.synopsis: The Coalition insists it supports the global Paris Agreement but it wants to dump Australia's short-term emissions reduction target. Is that allowed under the rules?

title.children: The Coalition's preparing to 'dump' Australia's 2030 climate target if it wins the next election. This is uncharted territory

image.altText: A man sits on a rock in the snow.

props.synopsis: In a play for legitimacy in the eyes of the rest of the world, the Taliban is looking to reignite Afghanistan's tourism industry. Some Australians are taking up the invitation.

title.children: 'Happy to see foreigners': Imogen visited Afghanistan and says she felt more unsafe elsewhere

image.altText: framed images of the victims of the Hunter Valley bus crash

props.synopsis: Twelve months after the Hunter Valley bus crash claimed the lives of 10 people, affected communities and first responders are still coming to terms with the tragedy.

title.children: 'People grieve in different ways': Emotions still raw a year after the Hunter Valley bus crash

image.altText: A man cuddling a dog

props.synopsis: The faithful pooch Blue travels about 6.4 kilometres to a campsite where his owner man had been staying with family, alerting them something is wrong.

title.children: Dog raises alarm after owner crashes car into ravine

image.altText: An archive photo of a man wearing a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Steele Hall's parliamentary career stretched more than 33 years, including stints in both the federal and state parliaments.

title.children: Former SA premier Steele Hall dies aged 95

image.altText: Frances Adamson with her arm around her mother Jennifer Cashmore

props.synopsis: Former Liberal MP Jennifer Cashmore AM, the mother of South Australian Governor Frances Adamson, has been remembered for her "trailblazing legacy" following her death at 86.

title.children: Former Liberal MP Jennifer Cashmore's 'trailblazing legacy' remembered

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Wall Street indices have lifted, but ASX has opened more than 1 per cent lower. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street lifts but ASX opens lower

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Will the RBA keep rates on hold next week?
Bonza staff have employment officially terminated
Total value of residential dwellings rises $209 billion in first three months of 2024

image.altText: A woman looks on with her hands behind her head.

props.synopsis: The A-League owners pushed for the split away from Football Australia, but they left the sport's governing body with the three biggest money-spinners: the Matildas, Socceroos and grassroots football. Now the professional league is at risk of collapse.

title.children: With Australia's national teams riding high, why is the A-League on the brink of collapse?

image.altText: An elderly Rendille woman holds her newborn goat outside her house in northern Kenya.

props.synopsis: A fisherman in Burma, a winery in France, and a wedding party in China are among the winning shots in this year's Food Photography Awards.

title.children: Here are 30 of the best snaps from this year's Food Photography Awards

image.altText: Close-up of woman putting a brown leather wallet in the back pocket of her jeans.

props.synopsis: Financial infidelity can range from some "low-key sneaky spending" on clothing, through to racking up debt on a secret credit card, or gambling away savings.

title.children: 'An enormous betrayal': Understanding financial infidelity

image.altText: Three people in front of granny flat, one in wheelchair

props.synopsis: For eight years, Linda Ryan's mother has lived in a granny flat at her home in Victoria's east, and, for the first time, she's been handed a $500 land tax bill, even though it is on her principal place of residence.

title.children: Should you be charged land tax on a granny flat in your own backyard?

image.altText: A group of protestsers in front of Germany's parliament at a demonstration against the far-right Alternative for Germany.

props.synopsis: Radical-right political parties have made significant gains in the European Parliament elections, as nationalist and populist groups continue to gain dominance in national settings across EU capitals.

title.children: What is the far right? Why nationalist parties are on the rise in Europe

image.altText: Two young white kids holding hands, running through long grass

props.synopsis: Studies suggest the absence of "risky play" in the modern world could be contributing to the teen mental health crisis. Here's what it's all about.

title.children: 'Just like I used to do': Why Peter wants to give his children an 80s childhood

image.altText: Older woman in the kitchen pouring a cup of tea

props.synopsis: By freeing up more properties for families, over-55 resorts could become a crucial part of the puzzle addressing Australia's housing crisis, according to the nation's peak retirement living body.

title.children: Could retirement communities be part of the solution to the nation's housing shortage?

image.altText: Two small elephants intertwine trunks next to a water body

props.synopsis: Wild elephants may be able to communicate with other members of their group by using sounds akin to names, a new study suggests.

title.children: Do elephants call each other by name, just like humans?

image.altText: BEATLES ADELAIDE GETTY JEFF HOCHBERG

props.synopsis: In 1963, the world's musical landscape was changing, thanks to four young men from Liverpool. And one meeting in July that year made sure that Australia would not be left out.

title.children: Australia got a Beatles tour in 1964 — it could easily have been Gerry and the Pacemakers instead
